entry.title: Rectangle RAG PCB
entry.summary:
Following some fun looking at outlines for laser-cut-traffic-light-cufflink.html I whipped up a quick PCB using KiCad. We quite surprised when all the components fit on the PCB and the routing was possible, I thought it would not work.

You can view all the raw KiCad files in the git repository. I test the gerber files at oshpark although I have not ordered them.

entry.title: Laser Cut Traffic Light Cufflink
entry.summary:
I had a play with a laser-cut rectangle case for the traffic light cufflink.

Key:-

  • Black - ATTiny45
  • Green - LEDs
  • Purple - switch
  • Orange - nylon screw
  • Brown - wire to cell
  • Silver - cell
  • Yellow - push connector to button

Still looks very tight to get the traces to fit on the PCB. This is with an outside case of 13.5 x 22.00 mm. As I write this, I have spun the LED by 90 degrees to give some space for the footprints. Very tight traces, time to run up KICAD and see if it fits.

entry.title: RGB Components
entry.summary:
I am tring to work out how many layers of laser cut acrylic I will need, in total. I am using 2mm acrylic.

I have used a nice python script to generate a dxf file than can be laoded on the laser cutter. It used the most excellent dxfwrite.

At the moment I have six layers:-

It would be nice to reduce this down by one or two. Limiting factors:-

  • Two x Cell battery CR1216 12.5 Ã— 1.6 height total: 3.2mm
  • PCB Thinkness 0.6 to 0.8mm thickness Total 0.8mm
  • Switch - found a (lovely switch 1.2mm height](http://www.mouser.com/ds/2/307/en-b3u-3615.pdf)

Giving at least 5.2mm, which means I can not (thanks to the switch) fit everything in just 5 layers. Top, bottom and 6mm inners. Time to sketch the PCB in https://www.tinkercad.com/

entry.title: Miniature RGB
entry.summary:
I designed a prototype PCB in kicad and then ordered a small batch of them from the great oshpark.com. I used interesting method to solder them, put the PCB on a standalone electric hotplate, move the components in to place with the aid of a USB microscope.

This actually worked, but proved I needed two cells to run all colours red, green and blue.

Wired up to a simple sketch, to give some random colours.

I have since improved the script a little to reduce the flicker.
